comments.text:
not really as at the apex of its leap (the moment/instantaneous point) 
between going up and going down it has mathematically no velocity. so 
assuming its trajectory from water to apex to you is a perfect one, then 
the amount of energy required to gain that altitude will equal the amount 
of energy gained falling from that altitude as the moment it leaves the 
water it is subject do deceleration due to gravity until the apex (when it 
is neither rising or falling) and then becomes subject to acceleration due 
to gravity which is the same rate as the deceleration. thus if we surmise 
that magicarp can survive the force of the water at the point it breaches 
the surface before the jump it would survive the force of entering water on 
the other side of the mountain at the end of its jump. but water is a lot 
softer than the ground so honestly these fish are playing russian roulette 
with there being water deep enough to absorb their impact on the other side 
of the mountain :)

comments.text:
From Bulbapedia: 
"Magikarp is based on a legend about how carp that leapt over the Dragon 
Gate would become dragons. Several waterfalls and cataracts in China are 
believed to be the location of the Dragon Gate. This legend is an allegory 
of the drive and efforts needed to overcome obstacles. This may have 
inspired an element in Pokémon Snap where, after certain steps are taken, a 
Magikarp will splash its way into a waterfall where it evolves. Magikarp 
may also be based on Asian carp, which are easily frightened by 
disturbances in water and can jump 8–10 feet (2.5–3 m) in the air."

captions.text:
Hey Vsauce, I'm Jake and we know that Pokemon
are deadly. Some are 1.7 times hotter than

the surface of the sun, others could blow
a hole through you with water jets, but thankfully

there is one Pokemon who is completely useless
and could never possibly kill you...Pokemon

Magikarp. Magikarp has the ability to leap
a mountain. And fish jumping out of the water

isn't that uncommon. The Silver Carp, also
known as the flying carp can leap 10 to 15ft...and

is actually pretty dangerous. According to
the Environmental Protection Agency, reported

injuries from Silver Carp range from black
eyes to broken jaws, noses, ribs and even
getting knocked completely unconscious.

Unfortunately for you, our fish isn't just
able to leap 15ft, no it is able to clear

a mountain and since there is no universally
accepted definition for the height of a mountain

we'll go with one of the UN's requirements
that it have an elevation of at least 8,200ft.

So now we have Magikarp, a 22lb fish falling
from a height of 8,200ft and right below it
is your head.

Because of air resistance Magikarp's terminal
velocity, the speed at which the air pushing

and gravity pulling reach an equilibrium,
would be around 131.2ft/s...about the speed
of a fastball...a 22lb fastball.

When Magikarp hits you, it's doing so with
enough pressure to crack concrete. So your

jaw, nose, your face would break in multiple
places and your skull would probably fracture

which is not good. But that might not kill
you, what would kill you is how fast your

head would accelerate immediately after impact,
the g-force.

Col. John Stapp, dubbed "the fastest man on
Earth", set out to find the amount of g-force

a human body could take and the effects. Stapp
and his team built a rocket sled capable of

withstanding 100gs and, on the very first
test, sent a dummy at a speed of 150mph then

hit the brakes. The dummy was subjected to
30g's, snapping the seatbelt and flying through

a wooden screen finally slamming into the
ground 710ft away.

Stapp then tested the sled out himself on
numerous occasions. He cracked his ribs, broke

his wrists, went unconscious a few times and
even lost a few fillings in this teeth. On

his final attempt, his sled was stopped in
1.4 seconds, subjecting him to 46.2g's, making

his body weigh almost 4 tons. He was barely
conscious and the capillaries in his eyes
exploded causing a redout.

Luckily his eye balls weren't ejected from
his head and a few hours later he regained

his sight...but here's the thing, 1g is you
just standing on the planet, existing. 3.5g-6.3g

is a drop on a roller coaster, 9-12g's is
your typical fighter jet, 50-75g's is serious

injury or death, then we get to 214g's and
race car driver Kenny Bräck which is the

most g-force anyone has ever survived. And
now we go to around 400g's which is how many
your head would be experiencing.

When Magikarp hits your face, that 22lb fish
is now more like 881lbs, and it goes from

131ft/s to roughly 0 in an incredibly short
amount of time, so that impulse, that change

in momentum transfers into you. Your neck
would snap back and, most likely, snap. Your

brain would probably slam so hard against
the inside of your skull that it would turn
to mush, all resulting in your fishy death.

But lets get a little extreme. Lets say there
is no air resistance to slow Magikarp down.

Now Magikarp would be hurdling towards you
at 726ft/s. 5.5 times faster than before with

the potential energy equal to 408 9mm bullets.
It takes about 224lbs of force to tear human

muscle, even less to tear flesh, and the fish
that's about to hit your face now weighs about

2.4 tons. To help visualize here is a clip
from Mythbusters where they sent a steel girder
travelling 65mph into a human sized dummy...

Obviously the girder weighs a bit more than
a fish, but it helps paint the picture. Upon

impact to your head, well, your head would
likely be knocked off your body, maybe a few

bits of muscle would be keeping it literally
hanging on, and your eyes and brain would
